questions.article: The reception of Hena Khan's book Amina's Song has been very good. Many reviewers, booksellers, and librarians have ______ the book, and it won the Asian/Pacific American Award for Literature.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: attacked

options.name: B
options.content: overlooked

options.name: C
options.content: recommended

options.name: D
options.content: misunderstood

questions.correct: recommended

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from Mary Seacole's 1857 autobiography Wonderful Adventures of Mrs. Seacole in Many Lands.

That journey across the Isthmus [of Panama], insignificant in distance as it was, was by no means an easy one. It seemed as if nature had determined to throw every conceivable obstacle in the way of those who should seek to join the two great oceans of the world.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word "conceivable" most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Possible

options.name: B
options.content: Regular

options.name: C
options.content: Visible

options.name: D
options.content: Basic

questions.correct: Possible

questions.article: Kelp forests grow underwater along the eastern Pacific Coast. These underwater forests are important to fish and other marine animals. Ocean currents can be powerful and rough, making it difficult for animals to find safe places to hide from predators. The underwater forests slow down the currents. This creates a more ______ environment with calmer waters where animals can take shelter.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: surprising

options.name: B
options.content: tranquil

options.name: C
options.content: imaginative

options.name: D
options.content: dangerous

questions.correct: tranquil

questions.article: The recently observed gamma ray burst GRB 230307A lasted for 200 seconds, ______ for a burst generated by the merger of neutron stars. Bursts caused by neutron mergers typically last fewer than 2 seconds.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: an incident

options.name: B
options.content: a reprieve

options.name: C
options.content: a coincidence

options.name: D
options.content: an oddity

questions.correct: an oddity

questions.article: Pteropods are small swimming snails with thin, delicate calcium carbonate shells. These animals are thought to be especially vulnerable to ocean acidification due to calcium carbonate's susceptibility to dissolution at lower pH values. Victoria L. Peck and colleagues recently found that the periostracum (a protective coating on pteropods' outer shells) prevents this dissolution when intact. Moreover, the team was surprised to discover that even when the periostracum is breached, pteropods can still mitigate damage by rebuilding the inner shell wall.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To call for additional research on biological mechanisms that improve pteropod survival rates

options.name: B
options.content: To address some of the ways ocean acidification has altered pteropod behavior over time

options.name: C
options.content: To discuss a conclusion drawn in a study of calcium carbonate's role in protecting the periostracum of pteropods

options.name: D
options.content: To present findings that suggest that a concern about the effects of ocean acidification on pteropod shells may be unwarranted.

questions.correct: To present findings that suggest that a concern about the effects of ocean acidification on pteropod shells may be unwarranted.

questions.article: Tokyo has high pedestrian traffic, but simply replicating a feature of Tokyo associated with walkability—e.g., its high population density—may be insufficient to induce increased walking in other cities. As urbanist Mariela Alfonzo argues, our understanding of individuals' decision-making about whether to walk is insufficiently robust: some studies emphasize the role of personal preference, others the role of perceived safety, and so on. But walking decisions are made in complex contexts in which multiple conditions and needs inform individuals’ choices.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To describe the effect of high population density on any given city's walkability

options.name: B
options.content: To present a claim about how individuals' decision-making about walking can be improved

options.name: C
options.content: To discuss the difficulty of identifying a reliable way to increase walking in any given city

options.name: D
options.content: To explain why it is challenging to compare the amount of pedestrian traffic in different cities

questions.correct: To discuss the difficulty of identifying a reliable way to increase walking in any given city

questions.article:
The following text is from Sarojini Naidu's 1896 poem "Alabaster."

Like this alabaster box whose art
Is frail as a cassia-flower, is my heart,
Carven with delicate dreams and wrought
With many a subtle and exquisite thought.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the two underlined portions in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: They describe the subjects, one physical and one abstract, of a comparison that extends throughout the text.

options.name: B
options.content: They symbolize two attitudes, one logical and one emotional, that are contrasted throughout the text.

options.name: C
options.content: They indicate potential reactions, one hoped for and one feared. to a decision the speaker considers throughout the text.

options.name: D
options.content: They provide examples, one literal and one figurative, of a change that the speaker describes throughout the text.

questions.correct: They describe the subjects, one physical and one abstract, of a comparison that extends throughout the text.

questions.article:
Text 1

When the 50-second-long film Arrival of the Train—which depicts what its title says, a train pulling into a station—was first shown publicly in 1896, spectators, naïve to the new medium of film and seeing a train appearing to come directly at them, leaped from their seats and fled the room. This moment marks a major cultural shift: a new way of representing and seeing the world had arrived with that train, and nothing would ever be the same.

Text 2

The fact that there is no contemporary evidence that the first audience of Arrival of the Train was alarmed has not stopped the story from becoming canonical, even among film historians. But that phenomenon itself is highly revealing. Our belief that the coming of film was transformative is so strong that we invented and keep retelling a founding myth that divides cultural history into a (naïve) "before" and (sophisticated) "after."
questions.question: Based on the texts, the author of Text 2 would most likely agree with which statement about the description of the first showing of Arrival of the Train in Text 1?

options.name: A
options.content: It is not based on evidence and reflects film historians' belief that they are more sophisticated than today's audiences.

options.name: B
options.content: It expresses a view about the transformative nature of film that film historians tend to regard as naïve.

options.name: C
options.content: It is more motivated by a perception of the significance of the invention of film than by facts.

options.name: D
options.content: It reflects a misconception that is widely believed because it captures carly film audiences' sense that the new medium was alarming.

questions.correct: It is more motivated by a perception of the significance of the invention of film than by facts.

questions.article:
The following text is from William Shakespeare's play The Tempest, first performed in 1611. Miranda has lived on an island with her father, Prospero, since she was three years old. Prospero has stated that Miranda likely does not remember anything other than her life on the island.

MIRANDA: 'Tis far off,
And rather like a dream than an assurance
That my remembrance warrants. Had I not
Four or five women once that tended me?

PROSPERO: Thou hadst, and more, Miranda. But how is it
That this lives in thy mind? What seest thou else
In the dark backward and abysm of time?
If thou remember'st aught ere thou camest here,
How thou camest here thou mayst.
questions.question: In the text, which point does Prospero most directly make about Miranda and her memories?

options.name: A
options.content: Miranda's impression of a scene is vague because she is remembering a scenario she had daydreamed about as a child rather than a scenario that had occurred in reality.

options.name: B
options.content: Miranda's doubts about the accuracy of one recollection of a place other than the island are clouding her judgment and seem to be making her reluctant to explore her recollection of traveling to the island.

options.name: C
options.content: Miranda's reminiscences about her early childhood have a melancholy quality that betrays her discontented view of her current circumstances.

options.name: D
options.content: Miranda's ability to summon details of an experience she had before arriving on the island suggests that she may also be able to summon details of her arrival on the island.

questions.correct: Miranda's ability to summon details of an experience she had before arriving on the island suggests that she may also be able to summon details of her arrival on the island.

questions.article: The Muscogee Nation and the nearly forty other tribes in Oklahoma operate numerous businesses and collectively generate billions of dollars in revenue. Mining, including oil and natural gas production, is a key industry in the state as well. While researching other key industries in Oklahoma for an economics class, a student finds that the average amount contributed to the state's economy in 2017 by each individual employed in wholesale trade was ______.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the statement?

questions.article: Poems is an 1895 collection of poetry by Frances E.W. Harper. In one of Harper's poems, the speaker declares her intention to create art that has a universal appeal across generations, saying, ______
questions.question: Which quotation from Poems most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: “Our world, so worn and weary, / Needs music, pure and strong. / To hush the jangle and discords / Of sorrow, pain and wrong.” (from “Songs for the People”)

options.name: B
options.content: “Let me make the songs for the people, / Songs for the old and young: / Songs to stir like a battle-cry / Wherever they are sung.” (from “Songs for the People”)

options.name: C
options.content: “God bless our native land, / Land of the newly free, / Oh may she ever stand / For truth and liberty,” (from “God Bless Our Native Land”)

options.name: D
options.content: “My mother's kiss, my mother's kiss, / I feel its impress now, / As in the bright and happy days / She pressed it on my brow.” (from “My Mother's Kiss”)

questions.correct: “Let me make the songs for the people, / Songs for the old and young: / Songs to stir like a battle-cry / Wherever they are sung.” (from “Songs for the People”)

questions.article: In a college course on urban affairs, a student asserts that increased traffic congestion in the United States in the 1990s was present both in very large cities such as New York City, New York, and smaller areas such as Albany-Schenectady-Troy, New York, and Beaumont, Texas; though those smaller areas may have been less affected by traffic congestion than very large cities, this congestion also worsened in them over time.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data from the graph that support the student's claim?

options.name: A
options.content: In at least one of the three urban areas shown, the amount of traffic delay was less than 20 hours per commuter per year at one point between 1990 and 2000.

options.name: B
options.content: In 1992, the amount of traffic delay in the New York City, New York, area was less than 30 hours per commuter per year.

options.name: C
options.content: While the annual number of hours of traffic delay per commuter was always lower in the Albany-Schenectady-Troy, New York, area than in the New York City, New York, area for each year between 1990 and 2000, the amount of traffic delay rose in both areas during this period.

options.name: D
options.content: Even though the amount of traffic delay per commuter per year was greater in the Albany-Schenectady-Troy, New York, area than in the New York City, New York, area throughout the period from 1990 to 2000, the amounts were nearly identical in 1996.

questions.correct: While the annual number of hours of traffic delay per commuter was always lower in the Albany-Schenectady-Troy, New York, area than in the New York City, New York, area for each year between 1990 and 2000, the amount of traffic delay rose in both areas during this period.

questions.article: Past research suggests that pollination by honeybees is responsible for up to 10 percent of total onion crop production. Now researchers are trying to determine how dependent cucumber crop production is on honeybees. The first phase of their study involved shielding some cucumber plants to prevent insects from pollinating them, resulting in those plants having 40 to 90 percent lower crop production than plants that were pollinated normally. However, the researchers claim that the first-phase experiment alone didn't tell them how much of that difference in crop production is due specifically to excluding honeybees.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support the researchers' claim?

options.name: A
options.content: Other insects like solitary bees also pollinate onion plants, and some studies have allowed them to pollinate normally while excluding honeybees.

options.name: B
options.content: Other insects like squash bees also pollinate cucumber plants, and the shielding in the first phase of the study blocked them as well.

options.name: C
options.content: Honeybees are more commonly used to pollinate cucumber plants than onion plants.

options.name: D
options.content: The shielding used in the first phase of the study did not affect the amount of sunlight the cucumber plants received.

questions.correct: Other insects like squash bees also pollinate cucumber plants, and the shielding in the first phase of the study blocked them as well.

questions.article: The Underdogs is a 1915 novel by Mariano Azuela, originally written in Spanish. In the novel, Azuela depicts a traveling group of soldiers as having a renewed sense of agency and authority as they set off on a new stage of their journey: ______
questions.question: Which quotation from a translation of The Underdogs most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: "The sonorous, joyful bells rang again, From within the church, the honeyed voices of a female chorus rose melancholy and grave."

options.name: B
options.content: "All day long [the soldiers] rode through the canyon, up and down the steep, round hills, dirty and bald as a man's head, hill after hill in endless succession. At last, late in the afternoon, they descried several stone church towers in the heart of a bluish ridge, and, beyond, the white road with its curling spirals of dust and its gray telegraph poles."

options.name: C
options.content: "The men threw out their chests as if to breathe the widening horizon. The immensity of the sky, the blue from the mountains and the fresh air, redolent with the various odors of the sierra. They spurred their horses to a gallop as if in that mad race they laid claims of possession to the earth."

options.name: D
options.content: "Before Juchipila was lost from sight, Valderrama got off his horse, bent down, kneeled, and gravely kissed the ground."

questions.correct: "The men threw out their chests as if to breathe the widening horizon. The immensity of the sky, the blue from the mountains and the fresh air, redolent with the various odors of the sierra. They spurred their horses to a gallop as if in that mad race they laid claims of possession to the earth."

questions.article: In 1988, Arizona ______ official fossil: the Araucarioxylon arizonicum, which is a Triassic period tree.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: lawmakers designated the states

options.name: B
options.content: lawmakers designated the state's

options.name: C
options.content: lawmaker's designated the state's

options.name: D
options.content: lawmaker's designated the states

questions.correct: lawmakers designated the state's

questions.article: Often anthologized alongside the ______ associated with the Black Arts movement—such as Gwendolyn Brooks and Jayne Cortez—bell hooks's poem Appalachian Elegy (Sections 1-6) stands out for its memorable last lines: “the covenant / between us / can never be broken / vows to live and let live.”
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: work's of other writer's

options.name: B
options.content: works of other writers

options.name: C
options.content: work's of other writers

options.name: D
options.content: works of other writer's

questions.correct: works of other writers

questions.article: The part of a compound that determines the compound's color is ______ the chromophore. One example of a chromophore is hemoglobin, which gives human blood its red color.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: called-

options.name: B
options.content: called;

options.name: C
options.content: called.

options.name: D
options.content: called

questions.correct: called

questions.article: Released in 1996, the AMD K5 microchip contained a single CPU, or core, to execute commands. Since then, the average processing power of microchips has increased so drastically—cores now number in the dozens, hundreds, or even ______ the once-revolutionary dual-core technology that replaced the single core chip can be found in everyday items like toasters and toothbrushes.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: thousands, that

options.name: B
options.content: thousands that-

options.name: C
options.content: thousands - that

options.name: D
options.content: thousands. That

questions.correct: thousands - that

questions.article: After finding information about Ronald V. Dellums, who represented California in the United States House of Representatives, the student discovered biographical sketches of two other Black Americans who served in ______ Ralph Harold Metcalfe of Illinois and George Henry White of North Carolina.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: Congress.

options.name: B
options.content: Congress:

options.name: C
options.content: Congress;

options.name: D
options.content: congress

questions.correct: Congress:

questions.article: When a given industry—water and electricity are two well-known examples—carries high infrastructural start-up costs and other barriers that discourage competition, ______ of just one or two suppliers per municipality. Such industries are known as natural monopolies.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: it often consists

options.name: B
options.content: they often consist

options.name: C
options.content: these often consist

options.name: D
options.content: this often consists

questions.correct: it often consists

questions.article: Cornelia Konrads is a German sculptor who creates art that seems to be part of its surroundings. Her sculpture entitled knotty stilts is built on the wall of a university building in the United States. ______ appearing as two support beams knotted together against the wall, it is cleverly placed into its environment, serving as an example of Konrads's approach.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: There,

options.name: B
options.content: Later,

options.name: C
options.content: For instance,

options.name: D
options.content: However,

questions.correct: There,

questions.article: There are three basic steps you should follow when planning a scientific inquiry. First, thoroughly research the question you wish to answer. ______ come up with a prediction (also called a hypothesis) about the answer to your question. Third, develop an experiment that can test the accuracy of your hypothesis.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: For example,

options.name: B
options.content: Second,

options.name: C
options.content: Therefore,

options.name: D
options.content: Instead,

questions.correct: Second,

questions.article: Upon first approaching artist Kurt Wenner's Dies Irae, a colorful scene painted on the surface of a cobblestone street in Mantua, Italy, one might assume a deep hole filled with life-sized, classically styled sculptures had opened up in the street. ______ by expertly applying the principles of perspective, Wenner created merely the illusion of depth.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Additionally,

options.name: B
options.content: Next,

options.name: C
options.content: As a result,

options.name: D
options.content: On the contrary,

questions.correct: On the contrary,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Atitalaquia is a municipality in the state of Hidalgo, Mexico.
  • Municipalities are governmental regions responsible for providing many public services to their residents.
  • One service they provide is street lighting.
  • Atitalaquia covers an area of roughly 63 km2.
  • Hidalgo is divided into 84 municipalities.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize the size of Atitalaquia. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Providing street lighting is just one example of the public services that municipalities provide.

options.name: B
options.content: Atitalaquia is one of 84 governmental regions, known as municipalities, across Hidalgo.

options.name: C
options.content: Atitalaquia—a governmental region in the state of Hidalgo, Mexico—provides many public services to its residents.

options.name: D
options.content: The municipality of Atitalaquia in Hidalgo, Mexico, covers an area of roughly 63 km<sup>2</sup>.

questions.correct: The municipality of Atitalaquia in Hidalgo, Mexico, covers an area of roughly 63 km<sup>2</sup>.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The Future of Nostalgia is a scholarly book by literary theorist Svetlana Boym.
  • The book provides a multifaceted exploration of the concept of nostalgia.
  • Chapter 9 describes nostalgia in the city of St. Petersburg in Russia.
  • Chapter 17 discusses various skeptics' takes on the concept of nostalgia.
  • In chapter 17, Boym writes, “The poethics of nostalgia combines estrangement and human solidarity, affect and reflection."
questions.question: The student wants to provide a quotation from chapter 17. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: In a discussion of various skeptics' takes on the concept of nostalgia, Svetlana Boym writes, “The poethics of nostalgia combines estrangement and human solidarity, affect and reflection.”

options.name: B
options.content: Svetlana Boym's The Future of Nostalgia provides a multifaceted exploration of nostalgia.

options.name: C
options.content: Svetlana Boym describes nostalgia in the city of St. Petersburg in Russia in chapter 9 of her book.

options.name: D
options.content: After describing nostalgia in the city of St. Petersburg in Russia, Svetlana Boym goes on to discuss various skeptics' takes on the concept of nostalgia.

questions.correct: In a discussion of various skeptics' takes on the concept of nostalgia, Svetlana Boym writes, “The poethics of nostalgia combines estrangement and human solidarity, affect and reflection.”

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Jean-Michel Basquiat was an American artist who produced more than two thousand drawings and paintings.
  • His work Untitled (Prophet I) was completed in 1982 and sold at auction in 2011.
  • Untitled (Prophet I) is composed of acrylic, oil stick, and paper collage on canvas and measures 5,655 square inches in area.
  • His work Catharsis was completed in 1983 and sold at auction in 2008.
  • Catharsis is composed of acrylic and oil stick on canvas and measures 6,750 square inches in area.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize how the two works are similar?

options.name: A
options.content: Composed by artist Jean-Michel Basquiat in 1982 and 1983, respectively, both Untitled (Prophet I) and Catharsis use acrylic paint as a medium.

options.name: B
options.content: Artist Jean-Michel Basquiat completed Untitled (Prophet I) in 1982, and Catharsis followed in 1983.

options.name: C
options.content: Artist Jean-Michel Basquiat's work Untitled (Prophet I) is composed of acrylic, oil stick, and paper collage, while Catharsis is composed of acrylic and oil stick.

options.name: D
options.content: Between artist Jean-Michel Basquiat's works Catharsis and Untitled (Prophet I), the former is the larger of the two.

questions.correct: Composed by artist Jean-Michel Basquiat in 1982 and 1983, respectively, both Untitled (Prophet I) and Catharsis use acrylic paint as a medium.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Onomatopoeias are words that imitate the sounds they represent.
  • Words that represent the same sound are often written and pronounced very differently from language to language.
  • This variation is due in part to differences in how the languages are structured.
  • “Khrok fi" is a Thai onomatopoeia that represents the sound of snoring.
  • “Bhnosh" is a Bengali onomatopoeia that represents the sound of snoring.
questions.question: The student wants to contrast two words that represent the same sound. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: The Thai word “khrok fi" and the Bengali word "bhnosh" are onomatopoeias that represent the sound of snoring.

options.name: B
options.content: Though they both represent the sound of snoring, the onomatopoeias "khrok fi" (Thai) and “bhnosh" (Bengali) are written and pronounced very differently.

options.name: C
options.content: Onomatopoeias, words that imitate the sounds they represent, are often written and pronounced very differently from language to language.

options.name: D
options.content: The Thai word "khrok fi" which represents the sound of snoring, is an onomatopoeia.

questions.correct: Though they both represent the sound of snoring, the onomatopoeias "khrok fi" (Thai) and “bhnosh" (Bengali) are written and pronounced very differently.
